name: 9-bromofluorene
Reason: 9-bromofluorene has a melting point that is influenced by its structural components relative to the base melting point of benzene, which is around 5.5°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be fluorene, which has a melting point of 95.0 degrees Celsius. The bromine atom introduces a significant withdrawing group, increasing intermolecular forces and melting point by approximately +20 degrees Celsius. The methyl group reduces the melting point by approximately -10 degrees Celsius due to the reduced molecular weight and the absence of a hydroxyl group. The two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion can significantly increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
